case_data.name: State of California v. United States
case_data.plaintiff_description: Eleven states — California, Colorado, Delaware, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Washington
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
The Clean Air Act of 1963 preempts states from regulating vehicle emissions, but waived this preemption in California in 1967 in recognition of the state’s technical innovation in this area. California state law reflected this waiver, and between 2023 and 2025, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) granted California’s requests for three waivers concerning regulation on Advanced Clean Trucks, Advanced Clean Cars, and Omnibus Low NOx. On May 22, 2025, Congress adopted three resolutions disproving these waivers, stating that they were unlawful under the Congressional Review Act (CRA). 

On June 12, 2025, eleven states —  California, Colorado, Delaware, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Washington — represented by the Attorney’s General of their respective states, filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States of America, President Donald Trump, and the Environmental Protection Agency and its Administrator. The plaintiffs argued that Congress did not have the power to negate a state rule after decades of the federal waiver existing. They contended that the defendants actions were (1) ultra vires, (2) arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), (3) unenforceable under the CRA, (4) a violation of the take care clause of Article II, Section 3 of the Constitution, (5) a violation of the separation of powers principle, (6) a violation of the principles of federalism in the Tenth Amendment, and (7) defiance of federal law by federal officials. The plaintiffs requested declaratory and injunctive relief with the ultimate objective of allowing EPA waivers to stand and declaring the congressional resolutions unlawful.

The case was assigned to Judge Haywood S. Gilliam. 

A series of groups went on to file motions to intervene as plaintiffs and defendants in the case. First, an association of over three dozen companies focused on promoting the adoption of electric vehicles, the Zero Emission Transport Association (ZETA), filed a motion to intervene as a plaintiff on July 25. Then, on August 4, thirteen corn growers' associations filed a motion to intervene as defendants, arguing that the Clean Air Act waivers for California allowed the state to abruptly cut off the sale of internal combustion vehicles (which use corn as a primary source for the ethanol in gasoline) and disrupt supply chains. On August 6, another group filed a motion to intervene as defendants, consisting of 3 companies: American Fuel & Petrochemical Manufacturers, American Petroleum Institute, and the National Association of Convenience Stores. They aimed to represent “producers, refiners, distributors, and retailers” of fuel in the U.S. On September 5, the Alliance for Automotive Innovation and the National Automobile Dealers Association filed a motion to intervene as defendants. On September 15, Western States Trucking Association, Inc., and Construction Industry Air Quality Coalition, Inc. filed the same motion.

The EPA went on to file a motion to dismiss on September 19. In the motion, the defendants argued that all three of California’s recent waivers should be struck in accordance with Congress’s regulations and that the action should be dismissed in its entirety.

The plaintiff states submitted a notice of two other pending actions on September 26, Daimler Truck N. Am. LLC v. Cal. Air Res. Bd. and Am. Free Enter. Chamber of Com. v. Engine Mfrs. Ass’n,  stating that these suits substantially overlapped with the case in question, and acknowledging that transfer may be appropriate if necessary.

On October 3, the defendants filed a stipulation and proposed order requesting a delay on their response deadline in light of the government shutdown on October 1. The court granted the stipulation on the same day, moving the deadline to the prospective end date of the shutdown.

This case is ongoing
case_data.summary_short:
This case was filed in response to Congress passing resolutions that voided 3 California statutes regulating vehicle emissions, asserting that the waivers to the Clean Air Act that allowed the statutes to be enacted were unlawful. The plaintiffs are eleven states, represented by their attorneys general, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States of America, President Donald Trump, and the Environmental Protection Agency and its Administrator. The plaintiffs argued that Congress did not have the power to negate a state rule after decades of the federal waiver existing. They contended that the defendants actions were (1) ultra vires, (2) arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), (3) unenforceable under the CRA, (4) a violation of the take care clause of Article II, Section 3 of the Constitution, (5) a violation of the separation of powers principle, (6) a violation of the principles of federalism in the Tenth Amendment, and (7) defiance of federal law by federal officials. The plaintiffs requested declaratory and injunctive relief with the ultimate objective of allowing EPA waivers to stand and declaring the congressional resolutions unlawful. The case was assigned to Judge Haywood S. Gilliam. 

Several groups went on to file motions to intervene as plaintiffs and defendants in the case from July through September, none of which have been granted or denied yet. The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss the case in its entirety on September 19.

Proceedings have been delayed due to the government shutdown on October 1, with the defendant's response deadline being moved to the prospective end date of the shutdown. This case is ongoing.

1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  When Congress directed the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 
3  to regulate harmful emissions from new motor vehicles, 42 U.S.C. § 7521(a), it also preempted 
4  States from setting such standards, id. § 7543(a).  But, recognizing that California had already 
5  developed deep expertise in vehicle emissions control and that the State suffers from severe air 
6  pollution challenges, Congress directed EPA to “waive” this preemption for California, unless 
7  record evidence supports one of three limited bases for declining to do so.  Id. § 7543(b)(1).   
8  2.  Congress’s choice to allow California “to continue and expand its pioneering efforts” 
9  (pursuant to preemption waivers granted by EPA) has meant that the State “act[s] as a kind of 
10  laboratory for innovation” for vehicular emission controls, thereby advancing a core value of 
11  federalism while encouraging technological innovation for the protection of public health and 
12  welfare.  Motor & Equip. Mfrs. Ass’n, Inc. v. EPA (“MEMA I”), 627 F.2d 1095, 1111 (D.C. Cir. 
13  1979); see also New State Ice Co. v. Liebmann, 285 U.S. 262, 386-87 (1932) (Brandeis, J., 
14  dissenting) (“It is one of the happy incidents of the federal system that a single courageous state 
15  may, if its citizens choose, serve as a laboratory; and try novel social and economic experiments 
16  without risk to the rest of the country.”). 
17  3.  This Clean Air Act waiver provision was enacted in 1967, and EPA has granted 
18  California more than seventy-five preemption waivers for updates to the State’s new motor 
19  vehicle emissions control program.  As Congress intended, these waivers have allowed California 
20  to “improve on ‘its already excellent program,’” to foster technological advancements, and to 
21  protect Californians from harmful pollution.  See MEMA I, 627 F.2d at 1110 (quoting S. Rep. No. 
22  403, 90th Cong., 1st Sess. 33 (1967)).   
23  4.  Between April 2023 and January 2025, EPA granted California’s requests for three 
24  Clean Air Act preemption waivers, authorizing enforcement of the State’s latest additions to its 
25  regulatory program, including the Advanced Clean Trucks, Advanced Clean Cars II, and 
26  Omnibus Low NOx (“Omnibus”) regulations.  See 88 Fed. Reg. 20,688 (Apr. 6, 2023); 90 Fed. 
27  Reg. 642 (Jan. 6, 2025); 90 Fed. Reg. 643 (Jan. 6, 2025).  Pursuant to Section 177 of the Clean 
28 
   1   
Complaint  (25-cv-_________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-04966     Document 1     Filed 06/12/25     Page 3 of 43
 
1  Air Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7507, other States—including Plaintiffs here—have adopted these California 
2  standards as their own.  
3  5.  On May 22, 2025, the Senate joined the House in adopting three Resolutions, 
4  purporting to “disapprove[]” these waivers.  H.J. Res. 87, 88, 89 (119th Congress). 
5  (“Resolutions”).  The President signed the Resolutions on June 12, 2025.  In so doing, the Federal 
6  Government “singled out” these waivers—and the underlying California regulations—for an 
7  unprecedented attack, South Carolina v. Baker, 485 U.S. 505, 513 (1988), employing a statute—
8  the Congressional Review Act (CRA)—deemed inapplicable by every nonpartisan arbiter and 
9  expert who analyzed the question.  The Plaintiff States—California, Colorado, Delaware, 
10  Massachusetts, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, and 
11  Washington—challenge these unlawful Resolutions, which purport to prevent these States from 
12  enforcing laws they have chosen to adopt within their jurisdictions. 
13  6.  The CRA was enacted to facilitate congressional review of certain federal agency 
14  rules.  5 U.S.C. § 801(a)(1)(A); id. § 804(3) (defining “rule”).  Where it applies, it creates a 
15  narrow exception to the filibuster that enables the Senate to adopt a resolution disapproving of a 
16  federal agency’s rule with a simple majority vote.  Id. § 802(d)(1).  The CRA also limits Senate 
17  debate over a given resolution to a maximum of five hours per side.  Id. § 802(d)(2).  If a CRA 
18  resolution disapproving of a federal agency’s rule is enacted, the targeted rule ceases to have legal 
19  effect.  Id. § 801(b)(1).  And “a new rule that is substantially the same … may not be issued,” 
20  absent further, specific congressional authorization.  Id. § 801(b)(2). 
21  7.  While all fifty States consented—through their Senators—to these expedited 
22  procedures for congressional disapproval of federal rules, no State consented to the CRA as a 
23  means for Congress to negate state rules.  Nor would any State have done so.  States do not so 
24  easily surrender “the dignity … of sovereignty” they retain in our system of government.  Alden 
25  v. Maine, 527 U.S. 706, 715 (1999).     
26  8.  Cabining the CRA to federal rules is also consistent with the principle that the 
27  Federal Government does not “impose its will on the States … lightly”—e.g., through a process 
28  with severely constrained debate.  Gregory v. Ashcroft, 501 U.S. 452, 460 (1991).  To the 
   2   
Complaint  (25-cv-_________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-04966     Document 1     Filed 06/12/25     Page 4 of 43
 
1  contrary, the Framers intentionally designed the Federal Government to “partake sufficiently of 
2  the spirit [of the States]” such that it would “be disinclined to invade the rights of the individual 
3  States, or the prerogatives of their governments.”  Garcia v. San Antonio Metro. Transit Auth., 
4  469 U.S. 528, 551 (1985) (quoting The Federalist No. 46, p. 332).   
5  9.  The Federal Government ran roughshod over federalism and separation of powers 
6  principles in applying the CRA to these three preemption waiver decisions.  It did so despite 
7  EPA’s decades-old, consistent position—reiterated in each of the three actions at issue—that 
8  preemption waiver decisions are not “rules” and, accordingly, “the Congressional Review Act … 
9  does not apply.”  E.g., 88 Fed. Reg. 20,688, 20,726 (Apr. 6, 2023).  The Federal Government also 
10  blithely disregarded the legal conclusions of every nonpartisan arbiter upon whom Congress 
11  otherwise relies for determining the CRA’s applicability—all of whom concluded that use of the 
12  CRA here would be unlawful.  
13  10.  In fact, the CRA has never before been used in any context that resembles this one.  It 
14  has certainly never been used, as it was here, to negate particular state laws.   
15  11.  The President, his EPA Administrator, and Congressional leadership took these 
16  unprecedented steps because they saw the CRA as a quick and easy way to “take … down” 
17  California’s regulations.  Times of San Diego, Republicans in Congress Are Preparing to Break 
18  Decades of Precedent to Block Climate Policy (Feb. 27, 2025) (quoting Senator Capito).1  They 
19  appear to have agreed with the argument that the CRA should be used—despite its obvious 
20  inapplicability—because “[w]aivers take years to roll back through the administrative process” 
21  and ”ordinary legislation … would have to overcome the 60-vote filibuster in the Senate.”  
22  Boyden Gray PLLC, Buschbacher, Conde Discuss How to Overturn CA’s EV Mandate in the 
23  Wall Street Journal (Jan. 9, 2025).2 
24  12.  With every step, the “workings of the National Government” failed to follow the law 
25  and likewise failed to honor the “special restraints on federal power over the States.”  Garcia, 469 
26  U.S. at 552.  The “extraordinary defects” in the “national political process” that produced these 
27 
 
1 Available at https://perma.cc/8GQV-LQEN, last visited May 15, 2025. 
28  2 Available at https://perma.cc/D59T-Q7JB, last visited May 17, 2025. 
   3   
Complaint  (25-cv-_________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-04966     Document 1     Filed 06/12/25     Page 5 of 43
 
1  Resolutions renders them unlawful and “invalid under the Tenth Amendment” and principles of 
2  structural federalism.  South Carolina, 485 U.S. at 512.  That Congress violated separation of 
3  powers principles along the way only underscores the unconstitutionality of the Resolutions. 
4  13.  This Court should declare that the Resolutions have no effect on the status or 
5  enforceability of state emissions control programs.  This Court should also require EPA to 
6  implement the Clean Air Act, including Section 209(b)(3), 42 U.S.C. § 7543(b)(3), in a manner

4  rule, along with its “proposed effective date” and other information, to Congress and the 
5  Government Accountability Office (GAO) “[b]efore a rule can take effect.”  5 U.S.C. 
6  § 801(a)(1)(A) (emphasis added).   
7  52.  Underscoring that it applies only to federal rules, the CRA defines the federal agency 
8  actions to which it applies by way of the federal Administrative Procedure Act’s (APA) definition 
9  of “rule.”  5 U.S.C. § 804(3) (cross-referencing 5 U.S.C. § 551).  The CRA then narrows the APA 
10  definition by, among other things, excluding “any rule of particular applicability.”  Id. 
11  53.  Congress has 60 session days from the agency’s submission to adopt a resolution to 
12  disapprove a particular rule.  5 U.S.C. § 802(a).  The text of such resolutions is prescribed by the 
13  statute as follows:  “That Congress disapproves the rule submitted by the __ relating to __, and 
14  such rule shall have no force or effect.”  Id.  The first blank is filled in with the agency’s name 
15  and the second is typically filled in with the title of the Federal Register notice announcing the 
16  final rule.  E.g., H.J. Res. 35 (approved Mar. 14, 2025).  After a joint resolution of disapproval, “a 
17  new rule that is substantially the same … may not be issued, unless [it] is specifically authorized 
18  by a law enacted after the date of the joint resolution disapproving the original rule.”  5 U.S.C. 
19  § 801(b)(2). 
20  54.  If an agency fails to submit an action that one or more members of Congress believe 
21  is a “rule” subject to the CRA, those members may ask the GAO for a determination.

23  Must Be Submitted to Congress 23 (updated Oct. 22, 2024).11  In that case, if the GAO concludes 
24  the agency action is or is not subject to the CRA, Congress treats that conclusion as dispositive.

3  55.  In the Senate, the consideration of CRA resolutions is highly expedited.  The CRA 
4  creates an exception to the filibuster, so that resolutions of disapproval require only a simple 
5  majority to pass.  5 U.S.C. § 802(d)(1).  And motions, amendments, and even debate are all 
6  severely limited.  Id. §§ 802(d)(1), 802(d)(2).  Specifically, debate about the resolution and any 
7  “debatable motions and appeals in connection therewith, shall be limited to not more than 10 
8  hours, which shall be divided equally between those favoring and those opposing the joint 
9  resolution.”  Id. § 802(d)(2).  Although other motions are not “in order” and thus not permitted, 
10  “[a] motion further to limit debate”—to less than 10 hours—“is in order and not debatable.”  Id.   
11  56.  The CRA also provides that “no determination, finding, action, or omission under [it] 
12  shall be subject to judicial review.”  5 U.S.C. § 805. 
13  57.  Nothing in the CRA—or the broader Contract with America Advancement Act of 
14  1996—indicates Congress was contemplating the use of the CRA to negate state rules or to 
15  otherwise alter federal limits on state authority.  To the contrary, the text of the CRA is 
16  exclusively concerned with federal rules promulgated by federal agencies.  E.g., 5 U.S.C. 
17  § 801(a)(1)(B) (referring to “the Federal agency promulgating the rule”).  So, too, were other 
18  parts of the broader bill that contained the CRA.  E.g., Pub. L. 104-121, 110 Stat. at 857 
19  (“fundamental changes … are needed in the regulatory and enforcement culture of Federal 
20  agencies”). 
21  58.  The absence of any mention of state rules or state authority is particularly telling

24  to judicial review—are entirely inconsistent with that principle.

17  they do so by way of unsupported references in a press release, FCC v. Fox Television Stations,

5  130.  In contrast with its power to “prescribe” federal vehicle emission standards under a 
6  separate provision of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. § 7521(a)(1)), EPA’s role “in a waiver 
7  proceeding” is thus “sharply restricted.”  MEMA I, 627 F.2d at 1121.  EPA does not determine the 
8  pollutants to be regulated, the stringency of the standards, or the speed with which standards 
9  increase in stringency.  California makes all those choices in a state rulemaking proceeding, 
10  before it submits a waiver request to EPA.  For its part, EPA determines only whether any 
11  “parties favoring denial of the waiver” have met their evidentiary burden to obtain that result.  Id. 
12  131.  Put another way, it is California’s actions here (not EPA’s) that are “designed to 
13  prescribe law”—namely, the emission standards and other requirements vehicle manufacturers 
14  must meet in the State.  5 U.S.C. § 551(4) (defining “rule”).  EPA issues an “order” as “a final 
15  disposition” of California’s request; and that order—like a licensing decision—either grants or 
16  denies California permission to engage in a course of conduct (i.e., enforcement of its regulatory 
17  program).  Id. §§ 551(6) (defining “order” and including “licensing”), 551(8) (defining “license”).
